questions.text: A 3-year-old child with achondroplasia presents with bowing of the legs. On examination, the legs appear bowed with the fibula longer than the tibia. Which imaging modality would be most helpful in assessing the characteristic skeletal deformities associated with achondroplasia?
questions.explanation:
X-Ray Findings of Achondroplasia
  • Vertebral scalloping
  • Shortened Pedicles
  • Thoracolumbar Kyphosis during infancy is common.

Shortened and widened metacarpals, leading to "trident" hands.

 
  • Short femur
  • Genu Varum
  • Long fibula
  • V-shaped Growth Plate at the upper tibia
  • Champagne glass appearance of Pelvis

questions.text: A 42-year-old woman visits her dentist with swelling and pain in her left lower jaw, along with difficulty chewing. She reports persistent bone pain, weakness, and fatigue. Recently, she has experienced kidney stones. X-rays of her jaw are shown below. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis based on the findings in this patient?

A newborn is delivered at term with severe skeletal deformities, including crumpled femora and beaded ribs. The infant is noted to have extreme bone fragility and dies shortly after birth due to respiratory complications. Which type of Osteogenesis Imperfecta (OI), according to the Sillence classification, is most consistent with these findings?
questions.explanation:
Sillence Classification of Osteogenesis Imperfecta

Type I

(Option A ruled out)
  • Inheritance: Autosomal dominant
  • Mildest form
  • Reduced production of procollagen (50% less collagen).
  • Bone characteristics: Generalized osteoporosis, bone fragility, frequent fractures, especially during childhood and reduced bone maturity.
  • Sclera appearance: Blue sclera due to thin connective tissue in the eyes.
  • Hearing loss: Conductive deafness
  • Growth: Mild stunting of growth.
  • Dental involvement: Dentinogenesis imperfecta.

Type II
  • Inheritance: Autosomal dominant
  • Severe qualitative disruption in collagen function (lethal perinatal form).
  • Bone characteristics: Extreme bone fragility, fractures, and deformities (accordion femur), Delayed skull ossification.
  • Sclera: Blue sclera present.
  • Lethality: Perinatal death due to extreme fragility.

Type III

(Option C ruled out)
  • Inheritance: Autosomal recessive or autosomal dominant.
  • Both qualitative and quantitative abnormalities in type I collagen.
  • Bone characteristics: Moderate to severe bone fragility, multiple fractures, Marked long bone deformities, coxa vara, and severe ambulation difficulties.
  • Sclera: Blue sclera in infancy, returning to normal hue in adolescence.
  • Other skeletal issues: Early onset scoliosis, triangular facies, frontal bossing, basilar invagination.
  • Stature: Extremely short stature, progressively worsens with age.

Type IV (Option D ruled out)
  • Inheritance: Autosomal dominant.
  • Qualitative and quantitative changes in type I collagen.
  • Sclera: Normal sclera.
  • Bone fragility: Moderate to severe bone fragility and deformity, especially in long bones and the spinal column.
  • Growth: Moderate to severe growth stunting.

questions.text: A 7 y/o girl is brought to the clinic with multiple fractures and a family history of bone fragility. An X-ray reveals several characteristic features, including wormian bones and thin cortices of the long bones. Which of the following radiological features is specific to osteogenesis imperfecta?

options.label: A
options.text: Fracture deformities in the proximal femur

questions.text: A 3 y/o child presents with multiple fractures, some in different stages of healing. There is concern from healthcare providers regarding the possibility of child abuse. Which of the following is most helpful in distinguishing osteogenesis imperfecta (OI) from Battered Baby Syndrome in a child with multiple fractures?

options.label: A
options.text: Family history of similar bone fragility

options.label: B
options.text: Multiple fractures at different stages of healing

questions.correct_answer: A. Family history of similar bone fragility

questions.text: Which of the following management strategies is most effective for enhancing bone strength and reducing fracture risk in this child with osteogenesis imperfecta?

options.label: C
options.text: Sheffield procedure for bowed long bones

questions.correct_answer: B. Administration of IV Zoledronate cycles

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding Parathyroid Hormone (PTH) and its effects on bone is FALSE?’

options.label: A
options.text: PTH increases serum calcium levels by enhancing calcium release from bone.

options.label: B
options.text: Chronic exposure to PTH decreases the number of osteoblasts and osteoclasts.

options.label: C
options.text: Intermittent administration of PTH can lead to a net gain in bone mass.

options.label: D
options.text: PTH indirectly stimulates osteoclasts through cytokines released by osteoblasts.

questions.correct_answer: B. Chronic exposure to PTH decreases the number of osteoblasts and osteoclasts.

questions.text: A 50-year-old man visits his physician due to persistent bone pain, particularly in his lower back and hips. His medical history includes fatigue and occasional kidney stones. X-rays are performed to evaluate his bone health. Which of the following X-ray findings is NOT typically associated with the possible condition of this patient?

options.label: C
options.text: "Salt and pepper" appearance of the skull

questions.correct_answer: D. Osteoblastic lesions in the vertebrae
questions.explanation:
Primary Hyperparathyroidism

About
  • An adenoma or hyperplasia of the parathyroid glands usually causes primary hyperparathyroidism.
  • Clinical bone disease occurs in less than half of hyperparathyroidism patients; they may present with either bone disease or renal stones, but not both.
  • More common in middle-aged women.

Clinical Features
  • Bone Pains: Tenderness in bones, especially in lower limbs and back, with weakness and pallor.
  • Pathological Fractures: Fractures from trivial injuries, usually in the dorso-lumbar spine, neck of femur, and pubic rami.
  • Brown's Tumour: Expansile bone lesions made up of osteoclasts, often affecting the maxilla or mandible.
  • Anorexia, nausea, vomiting, and abdominal cramps.
  • Renal Colic and hematuria due to renal calculi.

X-ray
  • Irregular, diffuse bone rarefaction.
  • "Salt and pepper" appearance in skull bones. (Option C)

 
  • Loss of lamina dura around tooth sockets.

  • Sub-periosteal resorption of phalanges and clavicles - Most characteristic feature. (Option A)

 

  • The central collapse of vertebral bodies and biconvex discs in the spine.
  • Coarse striations and cyst-like spaces in the pelvis and other bones.
  • Brown's tumour resembles a bone tumour, often in the maxilla/mandible. (Option B)

  • Extra-osseous features like renal calculi.

Other investigations
  • Serum tests- High calcium, low phosphates, and high alkaline phosphatase.
  • Urinalysis- Low calcium excretion and high phosphate excretion over 24 hours.
  • CT scan- Assessing parathyroid glands and ectopic parathormone secretion.

Treatment
  • Surgical excision of hormone-secreting tissue.
  • Orthopaedic Treatment: Protecting softened bones from stress; possible surgical correction of deformities after disease stabilization.
  • Urology Treatment: Removal of renal calculi and maintenance of renal function.

questions.text: A 45 y/o woman presents with muscle weakness and bone pain. Her laboratory results show the following: Serum calcium: 2.1 mmol/L (low) Serum phosphate: 0.8 mmol/L (low) Serum ALP: Elevated Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Parameter

Normal Range

Low (Causes)

High (Causes)

Calcium

2.2–2.6 mmol/L

Hypoparathyroidism, vitamin D deficiency, chronic renal failure

Hyperparathyroidism, malignancy

Phosphate

0.9–1.3 mmol/L

Vitamin D deficiency, familial hypophosphataemic rickets

Chronic kidney disease

ALP

Normal varies

Hypophosphatasia

Osteomalacia, hyperparathyroidism, Paget’s, metastases

questions.text: A 10-year-old girl presents with recurrent knee pain and multiple fractures from minor injuries. Examination shows normal sclera, bowed lower limbs, and height below the 10th percentile for her age. X-rays reveal long bone deformities. Which type of osteogenesis imperfecta is most likely in this patient?
questions.explanation:
Sillence Classification of Osteogenesis Imperfecta

Type I

(Option A)
  • Inheritance: Autosomal dominant
  • Mildest form
  • Reduced production of procollagen (50% less collagen).
  • Bone characteristics: Generalized osteoporosis, bone fragility, frequent fractures, especially during childhood and reduced bone maturity.
  • Sclera appearance: Blue sclera due to thin connective tissue in the eyes.
  • Hearing loss: Conductive deafness
  • Growth: Mild stunting of growth.
  • Dental involvement: Dentinogenesis imperfecta.

Type II

(Option B)
  • Inheritance: Autosomal dominant
  • Severe qualitative disruption in collagen function (lethal perinatal form).
  • Bone characteristics: Extreme bone fragility, fractures, and deformities (accordion femur), Delayed skull ossification.
  • Sclera: Blue sclera present.
  • Lethality: Perinatal death due to extreme fragility.

Type III

(Option C)
  • Inheritance: Autosomal recessive or autosomal dominant.
  • Both qualitative and quantitative abnormalities in type I collagen.
  • Bone characteristics: Moderate to severe bone fragility, multiple fractures, Marked long bone deformities, coxa vara, and severe ambulation difficulties.
  • Sclera: Blue sclera in infancy, returning to normal hue in adolescence.
  • Other skeletal issues: Early onset scoliosis, triangular facies, frontal bossing, basilar invagination.
  • Stature: Extremely short stature, progressively worsens with age.

Type IV
  • Inheritance: Autosomal dominant.
  • Qualitative and quantitative changes in type I collagen.
  • Sclera: Normal sclera.
  • Bone fragility: Moderate to severe bone fragility and deformity, especially in long bones and the spinal column.
  • Growth: Moderate to severe growth stunting.

questions.text: A 12-year-old boy with chronic kidney disease presents with bone pain, weakness, leg deformities, dry skin, and itching. Lab tests show elevated phosphate, low calcium, and high parathyroid hormone levels. What is the likely diagnosis?

A 45-year-old man with hyperparathyroidism undergoes parathyroidectomy. Three days postoperatively, he developed muscle cramps, perioral numbness, and carpopedal spasms. Laboratory investigations reveal low serum calcium, phosphate, and magnesium levels. Alkaline phosphatase is elevated. What is the most likely diagnosis?

A 55 year old man presents with an acute onset of pain, redness, and swelling in his right big toe. He reports a history of heavy alcohol consumption and is on thiazide diuretics for hypertension. Blood tests reveal a serum uric acid level of 500 μmol/L. Which of the following is the most likely underlying pathophysiological mechanism for his condition?

options.label: A
options.text: Overproduction of uric acid due to increased dietary purine intake

options.label: B
options.text: Reduced uric acid excretion due to renal impairment

options.label: C
options.text: Excessive conversion of uric acid to allantoin

options.label: D
options.text: Increased uricase activity in the liver

questions.correct_answer: B. Reduced uric acid excretion due to renal impairment
questions.explanation:
Stage

Details

Crystal deposition

Monosodium urate crystals deposit in joints and tissues due to hyperuricemia.

Uric acid production & breakdown

Uric acid is the final product of purine metabolism, primarily produced in the liver.

  • Normal uric acid levels: SUA > 420 μmol/L in men and > 360 μmol/L in women.
  • Uric acid then gets converted to allantoin.
  • Humans lack uricase enzyme, preventing the breakdown of urate to allantoin (more soluble). This leads to hyperuricemia. (Options C&D)

Renal urate handling

90% of urate is reabsorbed via URAT1 in the proximal convoluted tubules; further excretion/reabsorption occurs in distal tubules.

Crystal formation factors

Factors like pH, temperature, and the absence of natural inhibitors influence urate crystallisation.

questions.text: Which of the following are TRUE regarding acute and chronic gout?

options.label: A
options.text: Acute gout presents with tophi in the elbow joints

options.label: B
options.text: Acute gout presents with “Punched-out" erosions on the X-ray

options.label: C
options.text: Chronic gout does not present with any significant X-ray changes.

options.label: D
options.text: Acute gout affects the first metatarsophalangeal joints (podagra)

questions.correct_answer: D. Acute gout affects the first metatarsophalangeal joints (podagra)
questions.explanation:
Feature

Acute Gout

Chronic Gout

Onset

Sudden, often at night

Gradual, over-repeated attacks

Progression

Rapid, with severe pain within hours

Progressive, with long-term joint damage

Joint involvement

First MTP joint (70% cases, podagra), knee, ankle, elbow, wrist

Multiple joints, tophi in elbows, hands, ears (Option A)

Systemic symptoms

Fever, malaise, particularly in polyarticular cases

Usually absent

Resolution

Self-limiting, resolves in 5-7 days without treatment

Persistent joint deformity and erosive arthropathy

Tophi formation

Absent

Present, with deposits of monosodium urate crystals

Radiographic changes (Options B & C)

None or mild

"Punched-out" erosions with overhanging edges on radiographs

Comorbidities

Typically none with acute episodes

Associated with metabolic syndrome, cardiovascular disease

questions.text: A 50 year old man presents with a sudden onset of severe pain and swelling in his left big toe, which started during the night. He has a history of recurrent episodes of similar pain. On examination, the joint is red, swollen, and extremely tender. To confirm the diagnosis of gout, which of the following investigations is considered the gold standard?
questions.explanation:
Investigation

Purpose

Key Findings

Serum Uric Acid (SUA) Levels (Option A ruled out)

Identify hyperuricemia and monitor ULT
  • Hyperuricemia: >420 μmol/L (men), >360 μmol/L (women)
  • May be normal during acute attacks

Synovial Fluid Analysis (Option B)

The gold standard for acute gout diagnosis
  • Needle-shaped urate crystals
  • Strong negative birefringence
  • WBC count ≥2,000 cells/mm³

Radiographic Imaging (Option C ruled out)

Evaluate chronic gout
  • "Punched-out" erosions with overhanging edges (this is also called Martel’s sign/ G sign of chronic gout).
  • Tophi (radiopaque urate deposits)

Inflammatory Markers (Option D ruled out)

Assess acute inflammation
  • Elevated ESR
  • Elevated CRP

Other Investigations

Screen for comorbidities
  • Abnormal lipid profile
  • Abnormal blood glucose
  • Liver function abnormalities in related conditions

questions.text: A 58 year old male presents with a sudden onset of severe pain and swelling in his right big toe. His medical history includes hypertension and obesity. On examination, there is erythema and tenderness over the affected joint. A diagnosis of acute gout is made. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial treatment for this patient?
questions.explanation:
Treatment of Gout

Acute Gout

First-line Treatment

  • NSAIDs preferred (e.g., indomethacin, naproxen, etoricoxib).
  • "Decrescendo" regimen: Start high doses, and taper over 5-7 days.

Alternatives

  • Steroids if NSAIDs are unsuitable. (Option B ruled out)
  • Administration route: Intra-articular, oral, or intramuscular.

Colchicine
  • Effective but limited by gastrointestinal side effects (e.g., diarrhoea). (Option A ruled out)
  • Early initiation and gradual tapering are recommended.

Non-drug Measures

Rest, ice packs, splinting, strong analgesia.

Chronic Gout

Patient Education

  • Educate on gout management.
  • Lifestyle modifications: Weight loss, reduced alcohol and fructose intake.

Urate-Lowering Therapy (ULT)

  • Goal: Lower serum uric acid (SUA) below the saturation point.
  • Target SUA Levels: EULAR (European League Against Rheumatism) <360 μmol/L; BSR (The British Society for Rheumatology) <300 μmol/L.

Indications for ULT

  • Recurrent gout attacks.
  • Chronic gouty arthropathy, tophi, urate renal stones.

Shared Decision-Making

Initiate lifelong ULT with patient involvement.

First-Line ULT Agents

  • Xanthine Oxidase Inhibitors: Reduce urate formation.
  • Allopurinol: Drug of choice.
  • Starting dose: 100 mg/day, lower for elderly/renal impairment.
  • Dose titration until target SUA is achieved.
  • Febuxostat: Alternative for allopurinol intolerance.

Other ULT Agents

  • Uricosurics: Enhance renal urate excretion.
  • Examples: Probenecid, sulphinpyrazone, and benzbromarone (limited availability).
  • Generally less effective than allopurinol.
  • Contraindicated in urolithiasis.

questions.text: Which of the following statements about pseudogout is false?

options.label: A
options.text: Pseudogout is due to calcium pyrophosphate crystal deposition in joints.

options.label: B
options.text: NSAIDs are the first-line treatment for acute pseudogout attacks.

options.label: C
options.text: Corticosteroid injections are contraindicated for acute pseudogout.

options.label: D
options.text: Acute pseudogout presents with sudden onset and elevated inflammatory markers.

questions.correct_answer: C. Corticosteroid injections are contraindicated for acute pseudogout.
questions.explanation:
Presentation

Description

Asymptomatic CPPD

Presence of CPP crystals without noticeable symptoms.

Acute CPP Arthritis (Pseudogout)

Sudden onset of joint inflammation, mimicking gout. Differentiation from gout becomes difficult, especially if the first MTP is involved (Pseudopodagra).

Osteoarthritis (OA) with CPPD

Coexistence with OA, hypertrophic form with prominent osteophyte formation and synovitis.

Chronic CPP Crystal Inflammatory Arthritis

Persistent joint inflammation, resembling rheumatoid arthritis, with intermittent acute flares.

Method

Details

Clinical Examination

Assess affected joints for pain, swelling, warmth, tenderness, and motion limitations.

Synovial Fluid Analysis

Aspiration allows the identification of CPP crystals; harder to detect than urate crystals.

Laboratory Tests

Elevated ESR and CRP during acute flares indicate inflammation. (Option D ruled out)

Feature

Gout

Pseudogout

Crystal Composition

Monosodium urate (MSU) crystals

Calcium pyrophosphate dihydrate (CPPD)

Crystal Shape

Needle-shaped

Rhomboid-shaped

Birefringence

Negative

Positive

Colour (Polarized Light)

Yellow when parallel to the compensator

Blue when parallel to the compensator

Clinical Presentation

Acute pain, redness, swelling, podagra

Affects large joints, osteoarthritis-like symptoms

Common Triggers

Diet, medications, stress

Trauma, surgery

Demographics

Middle-aged men, postmenopausal women

Affects both genders equally, older adults

questions.text: A 5 y/o boy is brought to the emergency department with a history of frequent fractures and deformities of the legs. His family reports that he has not been getting enough sunlight due to living in a region with long winters and has a diet low in dairy products. Laboratory tests show low serum levels of 1,25-OHD and elevated parathyroid hormone levels. What is the most likely diagnosis for this child?
questions.explanation:
Feature

Calcipenic Rickets

Phosphopenic Rickets

Cause

Inadequate calcium intake (often vitamin D deficiency)
  • PHEX or FGF23 gene mutations
  • Intestinal phosphate absorption
  • Impaired or abnormal renal phosphate excretion. (Option B ruled out)

Calcium Status

Low calcium absorption leads to hypocalcemia

Normal or variable calcium levels

Phosphate Status

Hypophosphatemia due to a decrease in tubular phosphate resorption.

Hypophosphatemia due to renal or intestinal issues

Pathophysiological Mechanism

Activation of the parathyroid–bone axis for calcium preservation

Defective phosphate metabolism or transport

Associated Conditions

Primarily linked to vitamin D deficiency

Can be associated with conditions like Fanconi syndrome

Effect on Growth Plate

Reduced apoptosis of hypertrophic chondrocytes due to hypophosphatemia

questions.text: A 6-month-old infant is brought to the pediatric clinic due to multiple fractures, which the parents report occurred with minimal trauma. On examination, the infant has noticeable bowing of the long bones. The physician suspects a hereditary connective tissue disorder. What is the most likely classification of this condition?
questions.correct_answer: A. Osteogenesis imperfecta tarda type I
questions.explanation:
Osteogenesis Imperfecta (OI) - Classifications

Looser Classification

OI Congenita

(Option C)

Characterized by the presence of numerous fractures at birth.

OI Tarda

Fractures occur after the perinatal period

Falvo Classification

OI tarda Type I

 

Features bowing of long bones

OI tarda Type II

(Option B)

No bowing of long bones, with fractures being rare in this type.

Seedorff Classification

Tarda Gravis

Fractures occurring in infancy

Tarda Lewis

Fractures occurring in late childhood

questions.text: A 3 year old child with osteopetrosis presents with symptoms of cranial nerve compression. What is the characteristic X-ray finding most likely present in this patient?
questions.explanation:
X-ray findings in osteopetrosis

Rugger Jersey Spine (Also seen in renal osteodystrophy)

Sandwich Vertebra

Endplates of the vertebra become densely sclerotic resembling a sandwich.

Densely Sclerotic bones

questions.text: Which of the following is a feature of Infantile Malignant Osteopetrosis?
questions.explanation:
Osteopetrosis

Osteopetrosis, also known as Albers-Schönberg disease, is a rare condition characterized by abnormally dense bones due to defective osteoclast function, which impairs bone resorption.

As a result, bones become thickened but brittle, leading to structural abnormalities and complications. (Option A)

Types

Infantile Malignant Osteopetrosis

Features

Adult Benign Osteopetrosis

Autosomal recessive

Inheritance

Autosomal dominant

(Option B)

Early onset with severe symptoms, including growth retardation, genu valgum, abnormal skull development, cranial nerve entrapment, pancytopenia, and hepatosplenomegaly.

(Option C)

Presentation

Often asymptomatic and discovered incidentally in adulthood. When symptomatic, it may present with non-specific bone pain, compressive neuropathies, and recurrent fractures.

(Option D)

Increased risk of hydrocephalus, hearing loss, and osteitis of the mandible.

Complications

Delayed union

Symptom management with vitamin D, γ-interferon, erythropoietin, and corticosteroids.

Treatment

Generally not required unless symptoms are present. Symptomatic management includes pain relief and fracture care.

questions.text: A 30 year old male with achondroplasia complains of progressive lower limb pain, numbness, and difficulty walking. Imaging reveals lumbar spinal stenosis. What is the initial management plan for this patient?
questions.correct_answer: B. Weight loss and activity modification
questions.explanation:
Treatment of Achondroplasia

Management of Spinal Cord Compression

(Option A)

Proximal spinal cord compression, especially at the foramen magnum, is a life-threatening issue in infancy. Urgent surgical decompression and stabilization are necessary when significant stenosis is detected and if initial treatment is not beneficial.

Management of Infantile Kyphoscoliosis
  • Kyphoscoliosis is common in infants with achondroplasia but often resolves once independent sitting and standing are achieved.
  • Bracing can be used for persistent deformities, while surgery (e.g., anterior strut corpectomy and posterior fusion) is considered for severe cases.

Limb Malalignment and Lengthening Treatment

(Options C and D)
  • Guided Growth: Used in skeletally immature patients to correct limb alignment with minimal invasiveness.
  • Realignment Osteotomies: For skeletally mature patients, this surgery may be combined with limb lengthening or considered for severe malalignment.
  • This surgery can increase height in individuals with achondroplasia but carries risks such as non-union of bones, infection, nerve damage, and limb length discrepancies.
  • Knee Replacement: Total knee replacement is an option for joint pain due to advanced degeneration.

Management of Lumbar Spinal Stenosis

 

For lumbar stenosis, initial management includes weight loss, physical therapy, and modifying activities. Surgery is considered if non-operative measures fail.

questions.text: A 5 year old child presents with significant short stature, disproportionate limb shortening, and distinctive facial features, including frontal bossing and a button nose. The child’s developmental milestones are appropriate for age. Which of the following bone diseases is most likely responsible for this child's clinical presentation?
questions.explanation:
Feature

Description

Disproportionate Short Stature

Significant reduction in height due to short limbs.

Rhizomelic Shortening

Shortening mainly affects proximal segments (humeri and femora).

Characteristic Facial Features

  • Button nose
  • Frontal bossing
  • Macrocephaly
  • Midface hypoplasia
  • Small nasal bridge

Spinal Complications

  • Spinal Stenosis: Narrowing of the spinal canal causing claudication.
  • Proximal Spinal Cord Compression: This may lead to sleep apnoea in infancy due to foramen magnum narrowing.

Skeletal Abnormalities
  • Champagne glass pelvis
  • Horizontal acetabulae
  • Coxa vara
  • Bulbous proximal femora
  • Inverted "V" shape of the distal femoral epiphysis
  • Genu varum
  • "Trident hands" due to metacarpal shortening and splaying

Joint Laxity and Hypotonia

Causes postural issues such as:

  • Flat feet
  • Coronal malalignment
  • Fixed hip flexion
  • Lumbar lordosis
  • Radial head subluxation

Normal Intelligence and Lifespan

Individuals typically have normal intelligence and a lifespan comparable to the general population.

questions.text: A 65 y/o woman undergoes a DEXA scan. Her T-score is reported as -2.8. What is the most appropriate interpretation of this result?
Which of the following is not a complication associated with Paget's disease?
questions.explanation:
Symptom/Complication

Description

Cranial nerve compression

Causes vision impairment, facial palsy, trigeminal neuralgia, or deafness (otosclerosis).

Spinal cord/nerve root compression

Vertebral thickening leads to neurological symptoms (e.g., pain, and weakness). (Option D)

Steal syndromes

Diverted blood flow (from visceral organs to the surrounding skeleton) causes cerebral impairment or spinal cord ischemia; may present as spinal claudication and lower limb weakness.

Fractures

Common in weight-bearing bones, it slow healing, and can be painful.

Osteoarthritis

Typically affects hip or knee, especially with pelvic bone involvement.

Osteosarcoma

Rare malignant transformation (~1%), presents with increasing pain, swelling, and tenderness. (Option A)

High-output cardiac failure

Rare, results from increased blood flow to affected bones overloading the heart.

Hypercalcaemia

Occurs due to prolonged immobilisation. (Option B)

Excessive intraoperative bleeding

Surgery on pagetic bone results in increased bleeding.

questions.text: A 72 year old man with a history of Paget's disease of bone presents with worsening pain in his left hip and difficulty walking. Upon examination, his left hip is warm to the touch, and he has a noticeable deformity in the femur. Laboratory tests show elevated serum alkaline phosphatase (ALP) levels. X-rays reveal thickened femoral cortices with evidence of a stress fracture. What is the most appropriate initial management for this patient?
questions.explanation:
Biochemical Investigations

Serum Alkaline Phosphatase (ALP)

  • Elevated in most cases; indicates increased osteoblastic activity.
  • Reflects disease extent and monitors treatment response.
  • Normal in monostotic PDB.

Serum Calcium and Phosphate

Usually normal; may be elevated in prolonged immobilisation.

X-Ray Findings
  • Early stage: Localised osteolysis with flame-shaped lesions and stress fractures.
  • Later stage: Thickened, sclerotic bone with coarse trabeculation.

Bone Biopsy

Rarely needed; used for definitive diagnosis to visualise the mosaic pattern in bones.

Radionucleotide Bone Scans

  • Shows extensive uptake in affected bones.
  • Differentiates PDB from bone metastases (focal uptake).

Medication

Intravenous Zoledronate

  • First-line treatment; 4-5 mg infusion. (Option B)
  • Suppresses osteoclastic activity; normalises ALP levels and relieves pain.
  • Well-tolerated; flu-like symptoms may occur post-infusion.
  • Contraindicated in renal impairment (eGFR < 30 mL/min).

Surgery

Fractures

Surgical fixation for long bone fractures; may correct deformities, but it is not the first-line treatment. (Option A ruled out)

Osteoarthritis

Total joint replacement for severe cases, particularly in the hip or knee. (Option D ruled out)

Nerve Compression/Spinal Stenosis

Surgical decompression to relieve symptoms.

Pre-operative Zoledronate

Recommended to minimise intraoperative bleeding during surgery.

questions.text: A 68 year old man complains of persistent bone pain in his right leg and difficulty walking. He also reports that his leg has become visibly bowed over the past few years. Physical examination reveals a thickened and bowed right tibia. Laboratory tests show elevated serum alkaline phosphatase (ALP) with normal calcium and phosphate levels. X-ray of the tibia: Which of the following is the sign in the lesion above?
questions.explanation:
Disease Phase

X-ray Findings

Early (osteolytic) phase
  • Localised bone resorption often appears as "flame-shaped" lesions along the bone shaft. (Option C)
  • The skull may show osteoporosis circumscripta (well-defined areas of bone loss).

Later stages
  • Bone thickening and sclerosis with coarse trabecular patterns.
  • Stress fractures are visible as fine cracks on the convex surface of long bones.
  • Pathological fractures may be present.”

questions.text: A 70 year old male presents with increasing bone pain in his right pelvis and lower back. O/E, he has a noticeable enlargement of his skull, and his gait appears stiff. Laboratory investigations reveal elevated serum alkaline phosphatase (ALP) with normal calcium and phosphate levels. X-ray of the pelvis shows cortical thickening and bone enlargement. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Type

Features

Monostotic PDB

Affects a single bone. Serum alkaline phosphatase (ALP) may be normal.

Polyostotic PDB

Affects multiple bones, more common than in monostotic fo” rm. The most common bones involved are: the pelvis, tibia>femur, skull, spine

Familial PDB

Affects 15-30% of cases, with 30% linked to SQTM1 gene mutations.

Severe, Early-Onset PDB

Rare form caused by mutations in the RANKL gene.

questions.text: A 4-year-old child is brought to the clinic with pain in the legs and swollen gums. The mother reports increased irritability and difficulty walking. Upon examination, there is subcutaneous bruising and tenderness in the lower limbs. You suspect a vitamin deficiency and order X-rays. What X-ray findings would you expect in this child?

options.label: B
options.text: Dense lines between epiphysis and metaphysis, and a ground glass appearance

options.label: C
options.text: Widened epiphyseal plates and cupping of the metaphysis

options.label: D
options.text: Increased bone density with no fractures

questions.correct_answer: B. Dense lines between epiphysis and metaphysis, and a ground glass appearance

questions.text: A 3 year old child is referred to a paediatrician due to poor growth and leg deformities. The mother mentions delays in walking and a noticeable protruding abdomen. On examination, bowing of the legs and tenderness around the wrists are observed. An X-ray of the lower limb of the child is given below. What other radiological findings would you expect to see in this child?

options.label: A
options.text: Normal epiphyseal plate width, smooth metaphyseal lines, and no signs of bone deformities diaphyseal cortex

options.label: B
options.text: Delayed appearance of epiphyses, widening of epiphyseal plates, and rarefaction of the diaphyseal cortex

options.label: C
options.text: Cupping of the metaphysis, narrowing of the growth plate, and presence of subperiosteal erosions

options.label: D
options.text: Thickening of the diaphyseal cortex, normal bone structure, and no visible abnormalities

questions.correct_answer: B. Delayed appearance of epiphyses, widening of epiphyseal plates, and rarefaction of the diaphyseal cortex

questions.text: Which of the following features are associated with rickets? Craniotabes Scorbutic rosary Bossing of the skull Harrison’s sulcus Perifollicular hemorrhage Brown's tumour Widening of wrists
Which of the following is regarded as the best measurement of overall vitamin D status in the body?
